title: Family Patterns
description: Explore how your family of origin shaped your attachment style.

questions.text: How did my family handle emotional closeness?

therapeutic.rationale: Family closeness patterns become relationship templates. Warm-open families model secure attachment; reserved-caring families teach understated connection; inconsistent families create anxious attachment; avoidant families create distance comfort. Your family's closeness style lives in your nervous system.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different family closeness backgrounds explain different comfort levels. The reserved-family partner may feel overwhelmed by the open-family partner's expressiveness. Neither is wrong.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared family closeness backgrounds create understanding. You learned similar relationship patterns and will recognize each other's style.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How did your family do closeness? How does this show up in your relationship now? What would you like to do differently?

questions.text: What did I learn about expressing needs as a child?
choices: My needs were heard and met
I had to be quiet or suppress needs

therapeutic.rationale: Childhood need-expression shapes adult patterns. Heard-and-met children become secure; quiet-or-suppress children become avoidant; inconsistent-response children become anxious; burden-feeling children feel guilty for needs. Your relationship with needs was formed early.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different need-expression histories create different comfort. The suppress-learner may not understand the heard-and-met partner's ease with asking. Be patient with each other's learning.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared need-expression history means similar challenges. Two burden-feelers may both struggle to ask, creating unspoken needs.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What did you learn about expressing needs? How does this affect your relationship now? What would healthier need-expression look like?

questions.text: How was conflict handled in my family?
choices: Avoided or swept under the rug

therapeutic.rationale: Family conflict patterns become relationship defaults. Open-resolvers learned healthy repair; avoiders learned conflict is dangerous; explosive-families created hypervigilance; cold-withdrawers created distance as safety. You're likely to repeat or overcorrect your family pattern.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different family conflict patterns explain different responses. The avoider may frustrate the open-resolver; the explosive-family person may overwhelm the cold-withdrawal person. Name your patterns.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared family conflict patterns may reinforce habits. Two avoiders may never address issues; two explosive backgrounds may escalate easily.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How did your family handle conflict? How does this show up in your relationship? What would you like to do differently?

questions.text: What role did I play in my family?
choices: The independent one who needed little

therapeutic.rationale: Family roles shape relationship patterns. Caretakers become over-givers; independents struggle to receive; peacemakers avoid necessary conflict; achievers tie worth to performance. Understanding your family role helps you choose rather than default.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different family roles interact in relationships. The caretaker may enable the independent; the peacemaker may frustrate the achiever who wants engagement. Recognize inherited roles.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared family roles may create competition or understanding. Two caretakers may fight to give; two independents may both struggle to receive.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What role did you play in your family? Does this role help or limit your relationship? What would stepping out of the role look like?

questions.text: What attachment pattern am I healing from my family?
choices: Learning that it's safe to depend on others
Learning that closeness doesn't mean losing myself
Learning that people can be consistent
Learning that I'm worthy of love as I am

therapeutic.rationale: Family healing work reveals core attachment repair. Safe-dependence healing addresses avoidant patterns; closeness-without-losing-self heals engulfment fears; consistency-learning heals anxious patterns; worthiness-learning heals shame. Your relationship can be a place of family pattern healing.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different family healing creates complementary growth. The dependency-learner practices receiving while the worthiness-learner practices self-acceptance. You can help each other heal.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared family healing means similar growth edges. Support each other in the same area while being careful not to reinforce old patterns.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What family pattern are you healing? How is your relationship helping? What support do you need for this healing?
